str2: Timothy, a Christian of Lystra, helper of Paul. From time and theos; dear to God; Timotheus, a Christian.
A child, descendent, inhabitant. From the base of timoria; a child.

parse: Verb - Present Indicative Middle - 1st Person Singular
str2: From para and tithemi; to place alongside, i.e. Present; by implication, to deposit.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Dative 2nd Person Singular
str2: You. The person pronoun of the second person singular; thou.
A command, charge, injunction; a precept, rule of living. From paraggello; a mandate.
A primary particle; down, in varied relations (genitive, dative or accusative) with which it is joined).
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.

parse: Verb - Present Participle Active - Accusative Feminine Plural
str2: From pro and ago; to lead forward; intransitively, to precede (participle, previous).
Prophecy, prophesying; the gift of communicating and enforcing revealed truth. From prophetes; prediction.
On, to, against, on the basis of, at.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Accusative 2nd Person Singular
str2: You. The person pronoun of the second person singular; thou.
In order that, so that. Probably from the same as the former part of heautou; in order that.
In, on, among. A primary preposition denoting position, and instrumentality, i.e. A relation of rest; 'in, ' at, on, by, etc.

parse: Personal / Possessive Pronoun - Dative Feminine 3rd Person Plural
str2: He, she, it, they, them, same. From the particle au; the reflexive pronoun self, used of the third person, and of the other persons.

parse: Verb - Present Subjunctive Middle - 2nd Person Singular
str2: To wage war, fight, serve as a soldier; fig: of the warring lusts against the soul.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Properly, beautiful, but chiefly good, i.e. Valuable or virtuous.
Warfare, military service; of Christian warfare. From strateuomai; military service, i.e. the apostolic career.
